required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cystoinflation to Prevent Bladder Injury in Multiple Caesarean Sections
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Cystoinflation to Prevent Bladder Injury in the Adhesive Disease of Multiple Caesarean Sections

brief_summary.textblock: The healthy pregnant women with previous operative deliveries admitted for elective C-section will be counselled and conditioned informed consent will be taken to be included in either study group if dense pelvic adhesions will be found during their operation. Adhesiolysis will be performed using bladder retro-fill with 300cc saline in the cystoinflation group, and without retro-fill in control.Both groups will be observed for bladder injury rate,bloodloss,operativetime,urinary tract infection,micturition problems and fistula formation.

detailed_description.textblock: Investigators will conduct this study to find the effectiveness of cystoinflation to prevent bladder injury in women with adhesions of previous C-sections. This prospective analytic longitudinal study will be conducted in Lady Willingdon Hospital, a tertiary care teaching hospital affiliated with King Edward Medical University Pakistan, from August 2017 to July 2019, after approval by the institutional review board of King Edward Medical University, Pakistan. The subjects will be randomly allocated to cystoinflation and control groups. The healthy pregnant women with previous operative deliveries admitted for elective C-section will be counselled and conditioned informed consent will be taken to be included in either study group if dense pelvic adhesions will be found during their operation. Adhesiolysis will be performed using bladder retro-fill with 300cc saline in the cystoinflation group, and without retro-fill in control. We will assess primary outcome by observing bladder injury rate, blood loss and operative time. The secondary outcome will be assessed by Urinary tract infection, micturition problems and fistula formation during 3month follow up period. The cystoinflation will be considered effective if the proportion of bladder injury in the study group will be less than 50% of the control group.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Subjects will be assigned into cystoinflation group and control group after parallel assignment.Each group will be further divided into bladder injury arm and distension arm(No bladder injury arm)
study_design_info.masking_description: The participants and outcome assessers are kept blind by just entering the random number assigned to subject on the papers and notes are written without details of adhesiolysis.The completed outcome performas are sent to the assessers with only random number entered and without method of adhesiolysis.The random number file is opened only after recieving results from the statistician.The care providers in theater and principle surgeon cannot be blinded in this study.

primary_outcome.description: Rate of bladder injury,extent of injury including site,size and depth of injury
Amount of blood loss during C-section in cc and proportion of subjects transfused blood in each group
Time from incision till closure of skin

secondary_outcome.description: number of sbjects with fever and positive urine culture for microorganisms

secondary_outcome.measure: White cell count per high power feild

secondary_outcome.description: Dysurea measured on 4point likert scale from0-4,higher score means a worse outcome
Urgency measured on 4point likert scale from 0-4, higher score means a worse outcome
frequency measured on 4point likert scale from 0-4, higher score means a worse outcome
Urinary Retension measured on 4 point likert scale from 0-4, higher score means a worse outcome
urethral incontince measured on 4point likert scale from 0-4, higher score means a worse outcome
Bladder volume measured by USG in cc after micturition for urinary retension

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of subjects with Urinary fistula formation
secondary_outcome.description: abnormal communication between genital tract nd urinary tract

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of urinary catheterization and hospital stay
secondary_outcome.description: Time period in days during which Foleys catheter is kept in situ.

arm_group.description: Bladder will be recognized by observing its gradual distension during bladder retro-fill with 300cc saline to perform adhesiolysis.
Pelvic adhesiolysis will be performed without bladder retrofill.

intervention.description: Bladder retrofill with 300cc saline to distend the bladder to recognize bladder outline

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- • Healthy pregnant women of any age
- Two or more previous C-sections
- Gestational age between 38-40 weeks (confirmed by dating scan)
- Dense Adhesions of Tulandi scores 4 or more.
wemen who give informed consent to participate in the study
Exclusion Criteria:• Patients with medical disorders
- Bladder injury prior to group assignment
- Placenta previa
- Subjects experiencing micturition problems (dysuria, frequency, urgency, urinary retention, incontinence) prior to the study.

results_reference.citation: O'Hanlan KA. Cystosufflation to prevent bladder injury. J Minim Invasive Gynecol. 2009 Mar-Apr;16(2):195-7. doi: 10.1016/j.jmig.2008.11.011. Epub 2009 Jan 9.
Pandey D, Mehta S, Grover A, Goel N. Indwelling Catheterization in Caesarean Section: Time To Retire It! J Clin Diagn Res. 2015 Sep;9(9):QC01-4. doi: 10.7860/JCDR/2015/13495.6415. Epub 2015 Sep 1.

Abdel-Aleem H, Aboelnasr MF, Jayousi TM, Habib FA. Indwelling bladder catheterisation as part of intraoperative and postoperative care for caesarean section. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2014 Apr 11;(4):CD010322. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD010322.pub2. Review.

Joelsson-Alm E, Nyman CR, Svensén C, Ulfvarson J. Micturition problems after bladder distension during hospitalization in Sweden: "I'm not ill, just damaged for the rest of my life". Nurs Res. 2014 Nov-Dec;63(6):418-25. doi: 10.1097/NNR.0000000000000057.

patient_data.ipd_description: No: There is not a plan to make IPD available.The data will be made available to individual researchers on request after publication.
